vWashington House Rabbit Newsv

Volume 7  Issue 1 March 1998

Update on Fleas, and a Delicate Subject
By Susan Brown, DVM


IMPORTANT UPDATE ON THE USE OF FRONTLINE IN RABBITS

Since my last article on flea control in rabbits, it has come to my attention that there have been a number of deaths of rabbits apparently associated with the use of FRONTLINE (fipronil—produced by Rhone Merieux Companion Animal Products). These deaths have been reported by veterinary practitioners across the country. As I mentioned in my article in the last issue of Chicago House Rabbit News [reprinted in the September issue of Washington House Rabbit News], the company that produces this product does NOT authorize or condone its use in rabbits, therefore they cannot be held liable. With this new information in hand, I recommend NOT using Frontline in rabbits for any reason. There are other, safer alternatives available.

Editor's Note: Several severe cases of enteritis have occurred as a result of rabbits ingesting ADVANTAGE FLEA CONTROL while grooming their companions. If you use this product and have multiple rabbits in your household, please separate your rabbits for 12 hours after application.

A DELICATE SUBJECT

I would like to discuss a delicate but important subject in this issue. This is a subject that we would rather not even think about, but without this important diagnostic tool, our knowledge of rabbit medicine (as well as knowledge of medicine in all species of animals including man) would be sorely lacking. The subject is the importance of a postmortem, or examination of a patient’s body after death.

Death is an inevitable part of our experience here. I will not attempt to discuss the various philosophies associated with this phenomenon, but its existence is part of the normal cycle of nature. Whether you believe there is a rebirth after death or whether you believe it is an end, we cannot prevent it for ourselves or our pets. Unfortunately, western society spends a great deal of time avoiding the subject, pretending it won’t happen and taking desperate measures to try and stave it off, rather than accepting death as natural. Death brings with it an end, of course, a sadness and certainly grief, but it can also bring great relief from suffering, peacefulness and great knowledge.

The knowledge can come from what we learned from that being’s spiritual and physical existence here, lessons such as love, forgiveness, laughter and letting go.

We also can learn valuable lessons from that being’s physical body, such as cause of disease, effectiveness of therapy, effects of diet, environment and genetics—to name a few. Some of you will have spiritual beliefs that do not allow the physical body to be altered after death, which we can respect. But for those who do not have these beliefs, for those who believe the spirit leaves the body after death or that death is the end, then there is no harm in allowing that dear pet to teach us yet one last lesson, the lesson that only examination of the physical body can reveal.

The correct name for the examination of the physical body is a postmortem, "post" meaning "after" and "mortem" meaning "death". The term "autopsy" is used only for humans because "auto" means self and only refers to humans doing postmortems on the same species (self) which are other humans. Postmortems have been performed for thousands of years, primarily to determine the cause of death of the person or animal. Much of our medical knowledge comes from these examinations. Without postmortems, we would probably be hundreds of years behind in our ability to detect and manage disease. Therefore, the postmortem is vitally important to the future health and welfare of any species in question.

When should postmortems be performed? In order to gain the most useful information, a postmortem should be performed within 48 hours of death. It is particularly important to keep the deceased pet cool during this time. If the pet is kept at 70 F or higher then decomposition will be rapid and 48 hours may be too long. In general, it is best to get the pet to the veterinarian as soon as possible after death and to keep the body cool (below 60 if possible), but NOT frozen. If the tissues freeze, the damage caused by the ice crystals can make it impossible to make a diagnosis from a microscopic examination.

What actually happens during a postmortem of a rabbit? There are a couple of ways that it can be approached. In some cases, only one feature of the pet will be examined, say an eye, or the heart because that is where the problem was most prominent. However, most often the entire animal will be examined because we have found over the years that sometimes what is obvious during life is masking other disease that is only discovered after death. To get the whole or "holistic" picture, it is best to look at all the organ systems. To do this, it is necessary to make an incision usually from the neck to the tail (like a very long surgical incision) on the underside in order to be able to open up the body cavities and take a look. First everything is viewed in place and then the organs are examined separately. The cause of disease may be obvious to the naked eye, but sometimes it is necessary to take small samples of tissue and send them to a pathologist for a microscopic examination for a more complete diagnosis. The samples are usually small and can include just about any organ in the body including blood, intestinal contents and bone. Cultures can be taken from a variety of tissues to test for bacterial infection. Impression smears (a glass slide is placed on the surface of the tissue lightly and then the cells that cling to the slide are looked at under the microscope) can provide a quick evaluation of the health of a variety of organs. If the rabbit was exhibiting disease in the brain, it may be necessary to make an additional incision in the skull and take tissue samples. Since the incision is surgical in nature, it is possible for the veterinarian to sew up the wound after the postmortem is completed. If you would prefer that this is done with your pet, please discuss this with your veterinarian. This is referred to as a "cosmetic postmortem" which returns the animal’s physical body to as normal a state as possible.

Why should you have a postmortem done? After all, it won’t bring the pet back to life, so what is the point? The following are some of the important reasons to consider a postmortem on your pet:

1. If you have a multi-pet household, particularly if you have several rabbits, a postmortem may reveal disease that could potentially spread to others in the household. If disease is diagnosed through postmortem, then preventative measures can be taken. I can tell you that postmortems have saved literally hundreds of animals’ lives in our practice over the years because of the knowledge obtained when one of their cage mates died revealed a serious group problem.

2. A postmortem can reveal potential zoonotic disease (disease transmissible from animals to man) that could be problem for human members of the household, particularly those with immune suppressant diseases. Common examples of exotic animal zoonotic diseases are salmonellosis, psittacosis (parrot fever) and certain parasites. Although rabbits are not commonly carriers of salmonella and zoonotic parasites, they can exist and cause problems.

3. A postmortem can reveal the cause of death when it comes as a surprise. When a pet dies suddenly and unexpectedly, often we blame ourselves for negligence or oversight. This, more often than not, is untrue. Without a postmortem, we may never know what happened and not only will we continue to torture ourselves with second guesses, we will have no available information on any possible prevention with future pets (if there is a way to prevent it). We cannot completely CONTROL when an animal passes from this existence; it is going to happen eventually. We can however, try to understand when and IF we had any effect on the event. It is often a relief for our clients to know that the death was NOT something that they could alter or prevent in any way.

4. A postmortem can reveal the success or failure of certain treatment regimens. Without this feedback, we cannot know for sure if treatments that we use—including medications, diets and surgeries—are effective. With information from a postmortem, we can make improved therapeutic choices in the future.

5. A postmortem can reveal genetic, environmental and dietary problems. With knowledge of genetic problems we can hopefully stop breeding from such defects. With knowledge of environmental and dietary disease we can improve those areas. We have learned a great deal, for instance, about appropriate diets in rabbits from close examination of the rabbits who succumbed to poor diets we fed in the past. We can thank those early rabbits who passed on and the veterinarians that examined them for the improved health and longevity of our pets today related to improved diets.

So what is this going to cost? Postmortems can have a wide range of costs depending on the practice and what is accomplished during the examination. Some veterinarians offer postmortems free of charge only if it involves a patient who was under treatment at that hospital at the time of death. Others have specific costs involved depending on the size/species of patient or the extent of the postmortem. All veterinarians will charge for the pathologists’s fees if samples are sent in for microscopic examination because the pathologist is charging the veterinarian for that fee in addition to packaging the tissues, mailing them in and the time involved in interpreting the results.

In conclusion, a postmortem examination can be an extremely useful tool in continuing our quest for knowledge on the improvement of health in the rabbit. Discuss this issue with your veterinarian. Often veterinarians are hesitant to bring up the subject because it is so difficult to think about it at such a painful time. If you initiate the conversation, it will put the veterinarian at ease and allow for an intelligent discussion of whether or not a postmortem will be valuable in your pet’s case. Try to think about this subject and come to a feeling about it BEFORE the time comes, so you are comfortable with your decision. If you are not comfortable with a postmortem at any time, or with certain pets, your veterinarian will respect your decision and it will not be necessary to explain your position. This was your friend in life and it is ultimately your decision as to what happens after death.

Finally, on a more cheerful note, I would really appreciate it if you, the rabbit owning public who read these articles, would send me ideas on things you want to hear about! This publication is for you and we serve you best if we know what you want. Thanks for reading about and considering this difficult subject.

Dr. Brown is co-owner of the Midwest Birds & Exotic Animal Hospital, Westchester, Illinois. v

Reprinted from Chicago Rabbit News, Holiday 1997 issue.
